column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Measure the Distance to a Galaxy

#Text=With the advent of internet access to scientific papers and research , plus some know-how of relativity , it is now remarkably easy to measure , with significant accuracy , the distance to spiral galaxies without using luminosity or red shift .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Find a clear digital photograph of the galaxy whose distance you wish to measure .
#Text=These are available on the NED or MAST DSS websites .
#Text=Save the photo as a negative and print it on a printer .
#Text=Although this can be done on a computer screen using Gimp .
#Text=Draw a line along the major axis of the galaxy .
#Text=The spiral galaxy will have spiral arms which will cross the line you have drawn at regular intervals .
#Text=Make a measure of the distance between these intervals .

#Text=You may use a ruler on a printed out photo and take an average , or use the measuring device in Gimp , or use MATLAB to extract the pixels along the major axis and apply a fast Fourier transform onto the extracted set of pixels if you are a geek .
#Text=Find the particular width in arc minutes of the photograph , which you will have used when selecting it from NED or MAST DSS .
#Text=The photo will also have its width given in pixels .
#Text=Or , if you have used a ruler , you can measure the width of the photo in inches or centimeters .
#Text=The purpose of this is to convert the measured interval length between spiral arms along the major axis of the galaxy into arc minutes .
#Text=It is important to measure , or determine , this interval in arc minutes .
#Text=And with a little algebra , this is very easy to do .
#Text=You do not have to be a geek to do it .
#Text=Find out how fast the galaxy is spinning .
#Text=Luckily , a vast number of galaxies have had their rotation speeds measured and these can be found online . Look for galactic rotation profiles or rotation curves and find one for your galaxy .
#Text=There is a way to find out how fast a galaxy is spinning using line widths , but that is not covered here .
#Text=When and if you find your galaxy 's rotation profile , it will be a graph of rotation velocity vs radial distance from the centre of the galaxy .
#Text=The velocity of rotation will flatten out to some maximum velocity , almost always given in Kilometers per second ( kps ) .
#Text=You will need to measure this maximum rotational velocity as best you can in kps .
#Text=Ignore every thing about dark matter ; it is completely irrelevant .
#Text=Multiply the interval measure in arc minutes times the maximum velocity of rotation measure in kps .
#Text=Divide 3.12E9 by the result .
#Text=That is the distance to the galaxy in parsecs .
#Text=If you multiply that distance by 3.26 , that is the distance in light years .
#Text=Video
